Supercurrent as a Probe for Topological Superconductivity
in Magnetic Adatom Chains

Narayan Mohanta1,2, Arno P. Kampf1, and Thilo Kopp2 Center for Electronic Correlations and Magnetism, 1Theoretical Physics III, 2Experimental Physics VI, Institute of Physics, University of Augsburg, 86135 Augsburg, Germany
Abstract

A magnetic adatom chain, proximity coupled to a conventional superconductor with spin-orbit coupling, exhibits locally an odd-parity, spin-triplet pairing amplitude. We show that the singlet-triplet junction, thus formed, leads to a net spin accumulation in the near vicinity of the chain. The accumulated spins are polarized along the direction of the local ğğ\mathbf{d}-vector for triplet pairing and generate an enhanced persistent current flowing around the chain. The spin polarization and the â€œsupercurrentâ€ reverse their directions beyond a critical exchange coupling strength at which the singlet superconducting order changes its sign on the chain. The current is strongly enhanced in the topological superconducting regime where Majorana bound states appear at the chain ends. The current and the spin profile offer alternative routes to characterize the topological superconducting state in adatom chains and islands.

Artificial lattices of magnetic adatoms, such as Fe, Cr or Gd, deposited on a spin-orbit coupled conventional superconductor, provide a versatile platform to realize Majorana bound states (MBS), locally accessible via scanning tunneling microscopy (STM)Â PhysRevB.88.020407 ; Li2016 ; PhysRevLett.114.236803 ; Nadj-Perge602 ; Feldman2017 ; Pawlak2016 ; PhysRevLett.115.197204 ; Ruby_NanoLetters ; 2016arXiv160706353M . Unlike the heterostructure-based schemesÂ PhysRevLett.100.096407 ; PhysRevLett.105.077001 ; Mourik1003 ; 0295-5075-108-6-60001 , these adatom lattices can exhibit topological superconductivity (TSC) even in the absence of spin-orbit coupling (SOC) when the adatom moments within a chain form a real-space helixÂ PhysRevB.90.085124 ; PhysRevB.91.064505 ; PhysRevB.94.144509 . The adatoms act as magnetic impurities for the host superconductor and give rise to Yu-Shiba-Rushinov (YSR) states which hybridize to form a band dispersing within the energy gap of the superconductorÂ YU_acta1965 ; shiba_PTP1968 ; rushinov_JETP1969 ; 1367-2630-17-2-023051 . In suitable parameter regimes, SOC induces chiral TSC in the YSR impurity bandÂ PhysRevB.93.014517 ; PhysRevB.88.155420 ; PhysRevLett.114.106801 ; PhysRevB.90.235433 ; PhysRevB.93.094508 ; PhysRevB.94.100501 ; 0953-8984-28-49-495703 ; PhysRevB.94.060501 ; PhysRevB.93.024507 ; PhysRevB.91.064502 ; PhysRevB.90.180503 ; PhysRevB.90.060507 ; PhysRevB.89.180505 ; PhysRevB.89.115109 ; Hui2015 ; PhysRevB.94.144509 . An adatom chain, therefore, mimics the physics of the one-dimensional Kitaev modelÂ 1063-7869-44-10S-S29 which contains isolated MBS at the ends of the chain. Experimental signatures for the possible existence of MBS on magnetic adatom chains were reported in recent STM experimentsÂ Nadj-Perge602 ; Feldman2017 ; Pawlak2016 ; PhysRevLett.115.197204 ; Ruby_NanoLetters .

The broken inversion symmetry at an interface allows for a finite Rashba SOC. In the host sğ‘ s-wave superconductor, it combines with the local magnetic-exchange fields to produce spin-triplet, odd-parity, Â±px+iâ€‹pyplus-or-minussubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦\pm~{}p_{x}+~{}ip_{y}-wave pairing at the adatom sitesÂ 2017arXiv170505378R . Conversely, the exchange field at the adatom sites suppresses the sğ‘ s-wave order parameter. Therefore, the adatom sites possess an admixture of spin-singlet sğ‘ s-wave and spin-triplet Â±px+iâ€‹pyplus-or-minussubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦\pm~{}p_{x}+~{}ip_{y}-wave pairing. The spin-triplet correlations decay rapidly away from the adatom sites. An effective Josephson junction is, thus, formed in the vicinity of the adatom chain. A junction between a singlet and a triplet superconductor is predicted to accumulate spin because of the lifted spin-degeneracy of Andreev bound states (ABS)Â PhysRevLett.101.187003 . Concomitantly, Rashba SOC generates a persistent current, carried by the YSR states, around the magnetic impurities; the currents flow orthogonal to the local spin polarizationÂ PhysRevLett.115.116602 .

Here, we show that the two different mechanisms, viz. the singlet-triplet Josephson junction and Rashba SOC, jointly cooperate to reinforce spin accumulation and spontaneous current flow around the adatom chains. Due to Rashba SOC, the accumulated spin provides an additional source for a circulating current around the adatom chain. The accumulated spins are polarized perpendicular to the direction of current flow and parallel to the local ğğ\mathbf{d}-vector of the triplet pairing amplitude. The sğ‘ s-wave pairing gap at the adatom site acquires a sign change as the YSR states undergo a parity-changing phase transition when the exchange coupling is tuned beyond a critical strength. The directions of both the spin-polarization and the current are reversed at the same exchange-coupling strength at which Î”ssubscriptÎ”ğ‘ \Delta_{s} changes sign. The current is significantly enhanced in the topological superconducting regime and, therefore, can be used as an alternative probe for the identification of TSC and the experimental verification of MBS.

The pair of YSR states, originating from a single magnetic impurity in an sğ‘ s-wave superconductor, emerge from the continuum of bulk states and move symmetrically closer in energy within the bulk superconducting gap, as the impurity moment Jâ€‹Sğ½ğ‘†JS is increased. A quantum phase transition occurs with respect to the total spin of the ground state when they cross zero energy at a critical value Jcâ€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘ğ‘†J_{c}S (=1/Ï€â€‹N0absent1ğœ‹subscriptğ‘0=1/\pi N_{0}, where N0subscriptğ‘0N_{0} is the normal-state density of states at the Fermi levelÂ RevModPhys.78.373 ). Beyond Jcâ€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘ğ‘†J_{c}S, the YSR states move apart and approach the bulk continuum states. With a finite Rashba SOC and the inclusion of triplet pairing in the self-consistent calculation, there is a discontinuous change in energy of the YSR states for a single impurity at Jcâ€‹S=2.56subscriptğ½ğ‘ğ‘†2.56J_{c}S=2.56) rather than a smooth crossover, and for an adatom chain, the â€˜zero-energyâ€™ MBS appear within the same range Jcâ€‹1â€‹Sâ‰¤Jâ€‹Sâ‰¤Jcâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘1ğ‘†ğ½ğ‘†subscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†J_{c1}S\leq JS\leq J_{c2}S (where, Jcâ€‹1â€‹S=2subscriptğ½ğ‘1ğ‘†2J_{c1}S=2 and Jcâ€‹2â€‹S=3.9subscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†3.9J_{c2}S=3.9), as shown in Fig.Â 1(a) [see Supplemental Materials for details on MBS]. The critical numbers Jcâ€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘ğ‘†J_{c}S, Jcâ€‹1â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘1ğ‘†J_{c1}S and Jcâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†J_{c2}S are modified in the presence of finite SOCÂ PhysRevLett.114.236804 . Enhancing the triplet-pairing amplitude at the junction also increases the magnitude of the accumulated spins which are polarized in the direction of the local ğğ\mathbf{d}-vector (in Balian-Werthamer representation) of the triplet pairing amplitudeÂ PhysRevLett.101.187003 ; PhysRevB.80.024504 [see Supplemental Materials]. We observe a slight variation of Sysubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¦S_{y} in the topological regime, that however decreases with increasing chain length. The amplitude of Sysubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¦S_{y} follows the behavior of Im(Î”Ïƒâ€‹Ïƒtâ€‹3)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœğœğ‘¡3(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t3}), suggesting a close connection between the accumulated spin and the triplet pairing amplitude. Sysubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¦S_{y} changes sign at Jcâ€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘ğ‘†J_{c}S for a single impurity and at Jcâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†J_{c2}S for an adatom chain. The sign change in Im(Î”Ïƒâ€‹Ïƒtâ€‹3)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœğœğ‘¡3(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t3}) at Jcâ€‹sâ€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘†J_{cs}S is not reflected in Sysubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¦S_{y} owing to the small amplitude of Im(Î”Ïƒâ€‹Ïƒtâ€‹3)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœğœğ‘¡3(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t3}) near Jcâ€‹ssubscriptğ½ğ‘ğ‘ J_{cs}. The exchange coupling jointly with Rashba SOC control the sign-change in Sysubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¦S_{y} at Jcâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†J_{c2}S when Î”ssubscriptÎ”ğ‘ \Delta_{s} also changes sign.

Rashba SOC gives rise to an additional contribution to the paramagnetic current operator, the expectation value of which depends upon the magnetization profile. A magnetic impurity or a ferromagnetic island, proximity coupled to a superconductor, renders a finite spin polarization around the impurity or the island, giving rise to a SOC-driven currentÂ PhysRevLett.115.116602 ; PhysRevB.92.214501 . Hence, the spin accumulation near the chain generates a current in the superconductor which circulates around the chain. Driving a current via magnetism is referred to as the magneto-electric effectÂ PhysRevB.72.172501 . The contribution to the current operator ğ£sSâ€‹Oâ€‹C=(jsâ€‹x,jsâ€‹y)superscriptsubscriptğ£ğ‘ ğ‘†ğ‘‚ğ¶subscriptğ‘—ğ‘ ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—ğ‘ ğ‘¦\mathbf{j}_{s}^{SOC}=(j_{sx},~{}j_{sy}) originating from Rashba SOC is given by

jsâ€‹x/sâ€‹y=âˆ“Î±â€‹eâ„â€‹âˆ‘Ïƒ,Ïƒâ€²(Ïƒy/x)Ïƒâ€‹Ïƒâ€²â€‹(ci+x^/y^,Ïƒâ€ â€‹ci,Ïƒâ€²âˆ’ci,Ïƒâ€²â€ â€‹ci+x^/y^,Ïƒ).subscriptğ‘—ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¦minus-or-plusğ›¼ğ‘’Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptğœsuperscriptğœâ€²subscriptsubscriptğœğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğœsuperscriptğœâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–^ğ‘¥^ğ‘¦ğœâ€ subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptğœâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptğœâ€²â€ subscriptğ‘ğ‘–^ğ‘¥^ğ‘¦ğœ\displaystyle j_{sx/sy}=\mp\alpha\frac{e}{\hbar}\sum_{\sigma,\sigma^{\prime}}(\sigma_{y/x})_{\sigma\sigma^{\prime}}(c_{i+\hat{x}/\hat{y},\sigma}^{\dagger}c_{i,\sigma^{\prime}}-c_{i,\sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger}c_{i+\hat{x}/\hat{y},\sigma}).

following the Peierls-factor derivation of Ref.Â PhysRevB.47.7995 . The rising of Sx/ysubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦S_{x/y} at sites next to the adatom chain, induced by the singlet-triplet junction, leads to an enhanced current around the chain as described in Fig.Â 3. For a single magnetic impurity, the current ğ£ssubscriptğ£ğ‘ \mathbf{j}_{s} drops to a large negative value and changes its sense of circulation at Jcâ€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘ğ‘†J_{c}S where Î”ssubscriptÎ”ğ‘ \Delta_{s} changes sign. However, for an adatom chain, ğ£ssubscriptğ£ğ‘ \mathbf{j}_{s} rises to higher values at Jcâ€‹1â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘1ğ‘†J_{c1}S (a few percent of the critical current ğ£sâ€‹c=2â€‹eâ€‹Î”/Ï€â€‹â„subscriptğ£ğ‘ ğ‘2ğ‘’Î”ğœ‹Planck-constant-over-2-pi\mathbf{j}_{sc}=2e\Delta/\pi\hbar for the host superconductorÂ PhysRevB.49.6841 ), decreases non-monotonically and finally reverses its propagation direction at Jcâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†J_{c2}S as shown in Fig.Â 3(a)-(d). The non-monotonic behavior of ğ£ssubscriptğ£ğ‘ \mathbf{j}_{s} between Jcâ€‹1â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘1ğ‘†J_{c1}S and Jcâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†J_{c2}S, including the steps, may be envisaged as a conjugate effect of (i) decrease in Sysubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¦S_{y} of the accumulated spins and (ii) the step-wise increase in total Szsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘§S_{z} of the superconductor. The current is carried by the YSR states around the chain.

The magnetic-adatom chains have certainly received particular attention because of the existence of MBS at the chain ends. However, as our results demonstrate, the physics of the adatom chains contains far more intriguing aspects which originate from Rashba SOC. The accumulated spin polarization and the spin-triplet pairing amplitudes can possibly be detected by local spin-resolved probes with STM techniquesÂ 2017arXiv170100822G , while the orbital magnetic moment of the persistent current around the adatom chains should be measurable using scanning SQUID sensors. The existence of the MBS, as inferred from STM experiments, appears still ambiguous primarily because of experimental challenges in disentangling the MBS from the YSR states near zero energyÂ 1402-4896-2015-T164-014008 . The simultaneous detection of the circulating currents would therefore provide a further piece of evidence in support of TSC and the interpretation of the STM signals in favor of MBS.

For a particular choice of adatoms (Fe or Co) and their configuration on the surface, the parameters Jğ½J and Sğ‘†S are fixed and it is not possible to explore different phases in one experiment. The issue could be circumvented by applying a homogeneous magnetic field to rotate the spin polarization of the adatoms. In the current analysis, we assumed the adatom spins to point towards the zğ‘§z-direction i.e. perpendicular to the surface of the superconductor. Since Rashba SOC breaks the SU(2) symmetry, the YSR states depend on the polar angle Î¸ğœƒ\theta of the adatom spins and a topological phase transition can be induced by tuning Î¸ğœƒ\thetaÂ PhysRevLett.114.236804 ; Loder2015 . A magnetic-field rotation experiment may thereby tune to the topological regime using the circulating current as a probe. The phenomena, identified here, are equally applicable to islands of adatoms where MBS convert to edge-bound modes.

II S2. Majorana bound states in the topological superconducting phase

As made evident in Fig.Â 1 in the main text, the magnetic adatom chain exhibits topological superconductivity within the range Jcâ€‹1â€‹Sâ‰¤Jâ€‹Sâ‰¤Jcâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘1ğ‘†ğ½ğ‘†subscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†J_{c1}S\leq JS\leq J_{c2}S. To verify the Majorana bound states (MBS) appearing within this range of Jâ€‹Sğ½ğ‘†JS, we plot the LDOS profile corresponding to the lowest pair of energy eigenvalues for a square lattice of size 61Ã—61616161\times 61 with a 505050-sites long adatom chain for Jâ€‹S=1ğ½ğ‘†1JS=1 (non-topological phase) in Fig.Â F1(a) and for Jâ€‹S=3ğ½ğ‘†3JS=3 (topological phase) in Fig.Â F1(b).

For Jâ€‹S=1ğ½ğ‘†1JS=1, the LDOS profile is centered in the middle of the chain indicating that the Yu-Shiba-Rushinov (YSR) states are extended within the impurity chain. Instead, for Jâ€‹S=3ğ½ğ‘†3JS=3, the lowest-energy pair (Â±2.8Ã—10âˆ’4plus-or-minus2.8superscript104\pm 2.8\times 10^{-4}) comes close to zero and the LDOS is concentrated at the two ends of the adatom chain. These sharp features at the chain-ends are the signatures of localized MBS. The tiny energy gap (âˆ¼10âˆ’4similar-toabsentsuperscript104\sim 10^{-4} for Nimp=50subscriptğ‘imp50N_{\text{imp}}=50) between the two MBS arises because the two MBS which decay exponentially with distance, but hybridize in the middle of the chain. This hybridization gap reduces with increasing chain length.

III S3. Spin-triplet pairing at the adatom chain

To study the spatial confinement of the induced triplet pairing amplitude, we plot in Fig.Â F2 the profile of the magnetization, the singlet and triplet pairing amplitudes in the two-dimensional lattice plane.

We find that the induced triplet pairing is confined to the vicinity of the adatom chain and die off quickly at sites further away from the chain. The sğ‘ s-wave pairing gap Î”ssubscriptÎ”ğ‘ \Delta_{s} is significantly suppressed because of the local magnetization along the chain, as shown in Fig.Â F2(a)-(b). Interestingly, the triplet order parameters Re(Î”â†‘â†‘t,1)superscriptsubscriptÎ”â†‘absentâ†‘ğ‘¡1(\Delta_{\uparrow\uparrow}^{t,1}) and Im(Î”â†‘â†‘t,3)superscriptsubscriptÎ”â†‘absentâ†‘ğ‘¡3(\Delta_{\uparrow\uparrow}^{t,3}) reveal maximum amplitudes at the ends of the chain only in the topological superconducting regime, as shown in Fig.Â F2(c)-(d). It was, in fact, proposed that MBS on the boundary of topological superconductors have universal spin-triplet correlationsÂ Liu_PRB2015 . There is a sign change in Re(Î”â†‘â†‘t,1)superscriptsubscriptÎ”â†‘absentâ†‘ğ‘¡1(\Delta_{\uparrow\uparrow}^{t,1}) at the two ends of the chain indicating the realization of chiral pğ‘p-wave triplet pairing. The results demonstrate that a mixed singlet-triplet pairing is realized in the chain and, thus an effective Josephson junction is formed in the vicinity of the chain. The consequences of the Josephson junction is discussed in the main text.

In order to check the nature of the induced triplet pairing in the adatom chain, we plot the logarithm of the triplet pairing amplitude Î”t=Reâ€‹(Î”â†‘â†‘tâ€‹1)subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ResuperscriptsubscriptÎ”â†‘absentâ†‘ğ‘¡1\Delta_{t}=\text{Re}(\Delta_{\uparrow\uparrow}^{t1}) with Utsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡U_{t} in Fig.Â F3.

IV S4. Variation of the occupation number

With increasing impurity moment Jâ€‹Sğ½ğ‘†JS, the total Szsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘§S_{z} of the superconductor, for a single impurity, increases by Â±1/2plus-or-minus12\pm 1/2 (depending on the sign of Jğ½J) at Jcsubscriptğ½ğ‘J_{c}. For an adatom chain, the total Szsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘§S_{z} increases in steps of height 1/2121/2 within the range Jcâ€‹1â€‹Sâ‰¤Jâ€‹Sâ‰¤Jcâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ½ğ‘1ğ‘†ğ½ğ‘†subscriptğ½ğ‘2ğ‘†J_{c1}S\leq JS\leq J_{c2}S to the final value Â±(1/2)â€‹Nimpplus-or-minus12subscriptğ‘imp\pm(1/2)N_{\text{imp}}, as described in the main text. This increase corresponds to the spontaneous creation of quasiparticle excitations.

However, the quasiparticle excitations in BdG evaluation of the pairing Hamiltonian always come in pairs. This is reflected in FIG.Â F5 which shows the variation of the occupation numbers nâ†‘subscriptğ‘›â†‘n_{\uparrow} and nâ†“subscriptğ‘›â†“n_{\downarrow} of up- and down-spin electrons, respectively, with Jâ€‹Sğ½ğ‘†JS.
